Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Morehouse College is requesting funds for 30 African-American computing undergraduate students and eight computing faculty to participate in a collegiate planning workshop that will be co-located with the 41st Annual National Black Data Processing Associates (BDPA) Technology Conference & Career Fair. The workshop will be held at the Hyatt Regency Hotel during August 1-3, 2019. The workshop focuses on increasing the number of Black computing professionals at the undergraduate level.

Workshop activities will examine best practices and seek to articulate strategies for collaborating with the information technology industry to increase internships for historically underrepresented minority students pursuing computer science and information technology careers. Proceedings will be disseminated broadly to other institutions of higher education, particularly Historically Black Colleges and Universities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Morehouse College was awarded funds for 30 Black computing undergraduate students and eight computing faculty (not including the PI) to attend a collegiate planning workshop that was co-located with the 41st Annual National Black Data Processing Associates (BDPA) Tech Conference & Career Fair held at the Hyatt Regency Hotel Atlanta on August 1-3, 2019. Currently, no notable student organization focuses on increasing the number of Black computing professionals at the undergraduate level. The workshop was designed to be used to develop collegiate chapters (primarily at HBCUs and predominantly Black institutions) to serve this purpose. The workshop also included BDPA board members, government agency representatives, and industry professionals. In addition to forming student chapters, the group planned to examine best practices and seek to articulate strategies for collaborating with the IT industry. This initiative is vitally important given the workforce development goals of the National Science Foundation and the need to broaden participation in computing. 

Major activities completed during the award include the execution of the workshop and the exposure to Black undergraduate computing majors to BDPA. More importantly qualitative (mostly) and quantitative data was collected from the workshop on what needs do these students have. This was CRITICAL in laying out the value proposition for students to join, faculty members to advise and for companies to sponsor the effort.

The workshop ended up focusing more on extracting thoughts and ideas that would make sense for integration into the strategic plan for the organization, than making specific decisions about the framework of the student organization . One piece of consistent feedback from faculty and students centered around the need for a CLEAR rationale for students and faculty to dedicate the time to start these chapters up. With that in mind, the workshop was successful in developing that rationale. Three main themes presented themselves as items of need and how these chapters can address them: a) exposure to emerging computing technologies/trends/careers, b) increasing career readiness (both technical and non-technical) and c) increasing self-efficacy in computing careers. 

One other outcome of the workshop focused on the faculty. Faculty indicated they wanted to improve their ability to leverage tools and technologies not available in their institutions which shows a disparity in technical resources available. Faculty were also interested in improving their collaborations with each other (i.e. Black faculty at PBIs/HBCUs), create collaborations with industry, craft community service opportunities, and write successful grant proposals. This finding could create the justification for faculty to pursue involvement with the BDPA student chapters.  

The data collected at the workshop was not only applicable to BDPA. The information is extremely valuable for companies who want to invest in capacity building for HBCU computing departments. For example, Dell Technologies has already included data from this study to include in an internal report (included in this report) that could influence future investments for their HBCU partners. 

The data collected in this award could lead to additional support from industry that would support programming intended to increase the number of Black and African Americans who work in computing fields.
